description: Adolescents, loosely defined (precise age range varies); may overlap +children and +adult. You can optionally create custom attributes in addition to this to add precise age ranges, e.g. "+adolescents +age12_17".

Adults, loosely defined (precise age range varies); may overlap +adolescents and +elderly. You can optionally create custom attributes in addition to this to add precise age ranges, e.g. "+adults +age18_64".

The associated hashtag applies to non-adults, loosely defined (precise age range varies; may overlap +infants and +adolescents). You can optionally create custom attributes in addition to this to add precise age ranges, e.g. "+children +age3_11".
Elderly people, loosely defined (precise age range varies). May overlap +adults. You can optionally create custom attributes in addition to this to add precise age ranges, e.g. "+elderly +age65plus".
Female people. See also +m and +i.
Households (vs +ind for individual people). The exact definition of "household" may vary among aid organisations.
Intersex or non-gender-binary people. Use this attribute for any groups who do not identify as male (+m) or female (+f).
Individual people (vs +hh for households).
Infant children, loosely defined (precise age range varies; may overlap +children). You can optionally create custom attributes in addition to this to add precise age ranges, e.g. "+infants +age0_2".
Male people. See also +f and +i.
The implementers classify this activity as an "activity" proper (may imply different hierarchical levels in different contexts).
Identifies a sector as a formal IASC humanitarian cluster.
Funding org/agency (e.g. donor).
Implementing partner.
Programming org/agency.
The implementers classify this activity as a "programme" (may imply different hierarchical levels in different contexts).
The implementers classify this activity as a "project" (may imply different hierarchical levels in different contexts).
Refers to a #service, #item, etc. that has been provided to people in need.
Refers to a #service, #item, etc. that affected people have actually consumed or otherwise taken advantage of.
A unique, machine-readable code.
Types or categories. Use with #org, #loc, #indicator, etc to provide classification information.
Boundary data (e.g. inline GeoJSON).
Geodetic coordinates (lat+lon together).
Place of destination (intended or actual).
Elevation above sea level (usually metres).
Latitude (decimal degrees preferred).
Longitude (decimal degrees preferred).
The data describes places of origin (intended or actual), e.g. the country of origin for displaced people.
Date or time when something was approved.
Date or time when something (e.g. an #activity) was canceled.
Date or time used for converting a monetary value to another currency.
Date or time when something finished or will finish.
Date or time when something took place.
Date or time when the information was reported.
Date or time when something started or will start.
Hashtag refers to people who have been abducted.
Displaced people or households. Refers to all types of displacement: use +idps or +refugees to be more specific.
Internally-displaced people or households. More specific than +displaced.
Located in camps.
People infected with a disease.
People injured.
People killed.
Not located in camps.
Refugee people or households. More specific than +displaced.
Email address.
Use with #meta to provide internal identifiers for data records.
Text labels (for a table or chart).
Human-readable name, title, or label.
The data consists of quantitative, numeric information.
The data consists of #contact phone numbers.
Information source for the data in the row or record.
The data consists of qualitative, narrative textual information.
The data consists of web links related to the main hashtag (e.g. for an #org, #service, #activity, #loc, etc).
